content.description:
If anyone knows the name of this route, let me know and I will change it.  There is also another route between this route and "Butterfly Flats" that is not in the guidebook. 

  Start on slabby rock, stem up to ledge, fight with a small tree, then head up low-angle edges to top.
content.protection: Bolts and gear (small cams) with chain anchors
content.location: Face just left of chimney ("Chimney Cricket" in the guidebook).  Second bolt is more or less directly above the first but out of sight from the ground.  Another bolt at the same height but ten feet left (and serving no apparent purpose) can be seen on the face to the left.  Stay right.

content.description:
Fun little spire! 

  Why wouldn't you climb this little guy if you were in the area???!!!
content.protection: 2 bolts and some gear on the SW face.   Chains.

content.description: Between Arputso and Bogus Excitement. Starts same as Bogus, but moves out left to bolts.
content.protection:
5 bolts and 2 pieces to chain anchors.  A set of nuts and cams to .3 is sufficient. 

  It is possible to top rope this route by scrambling around the back side of the towers.
content.location: Connect the dots, then lower off.

content.description: At the top of the tunnel described in the area description, look left to see two routes.  The right (three bolts)  is "Mo So Low" and the left is "So Low".  Start on the face left of the chimney crack to approach the first bolt from the right side.  Move up an onto the face above the bolt and proceed up the left hand face to chains.  There is plenty of opportunity for protection.  This route is probably half a grade tougher than "Mo So Low".
content.protection: two bolts, small cams and nuts.  Lots of solid nut placements.

climbs.name: Racing The Moon
climbs.fa: Chris Henze, Eric Fazio-Rhicard, Cyrena Goodrich, Mark Hathaway, '88

content.description: Start in a short, shallow dihedral that is naturally protected. Start clipping bolts and climb through a lower angle section of moderate difficulty. Rest on a ledge and clip the bolt before the reachy crux. Climb on good holds to a flake and get a few small pieces in before the exciting finish. The moves are interesting, the rock quality good, and the bolt spacing and pro added some spice.
content.protection: It is mostly bolted but most people will use small nuts and micro cams for the beginning and the end.  There are chains and a directional bolt on top.
content.location: This is near the bottom of the gully that most people will use to climb out of and into Bare Ass and Turret Rocks. There are two pretty big cliffs separated by a chimney. This route starts on the right side of the left cliff. It starts in a shallow right facing dihedral that quickly turns into a face.

content.description: All the way down the hill at Turret rock to a crack on the left edge of the quite narrow west face.  Follow the crack to the chains.
content.protection: Standard rack - the cracks will eat up all the gear you can feed it.

content.description: Short groove to short fat crack climbing at it's best.
content.protection: Light rack micro cams to #4 Camalot.

content.description: Climbs past a bolt to big ledge then you can go up the corner with gear or finger traverse left around arete to a bolt on the face then up past more bolts.  Better to stay in the corner.
content.protection: Thin gear up to green camalot even though you will only place to or three pieces.
content.location: Second to the left of Chimney Cricket.

content.description: It is a real roof crack with finger locks and hand jams.  More of a roped boulder problem than a climb.  Low angle climbing leads to a 7ft. roof crack.  Figuring out how to turn the lip might leave you hanging.
content.location: About 200 ft. west of Bownorthman and Bare Ass Rocks.  There is a tower between the two (Reaching Out Tower) with a route on it.  The climb is on the short wall up hill from RO tower

content.description: The crux comes about 20ft. off the deck and is well protected via a bolt.  This is a pretty stiff crux for a 5.9, but this is what squeezing the lemmon calls it.  At the last "bulge" before the finishing slab one can go left and probably get pro or stick with the line and go for the 5.8R slab.  Moving way right here is wild and fun!
content.protection: One bolt at the crux and the rest is all gear with chains at the top (shared with rabbit tracks)
content.location: This route is right of rabbit tracks about 10ft.  Look for the lone bolt.

content.description: From the top of the "tunnel", look left.  This wall will have three bolts protecting friction moves to chains.

As you approach the area as described above, you will go under a big slab boulder.  This is the "tunnel" I described in the approach.  As you go through this, the rock to your right is Jambrosia Tower.  The route Jambrosia is on the far side of this tower (South).  There is a left-facing corner near a large pine tree.  This corner is Just For Grins, 5.6*.  Just to the left of this corner is a steep hand and fist crack that appears to be an offwidth (trust me, its hands and fists).  This crack is Jambrosia.  Climb this in one pitch to the chimney.  You can wriggle up to the top and descend via chains on the East side OR you can wriggle across it to a small pine tree, and walkoff/downclimb to the north and back above the "tunnel".
content.protection: The route appears wider from the ground than it really is.  Cams up to about #2 Camalot should suffice.  You may want a double of #1.  You shouldn't need small stoppers or small cams.

content.description: Stem the corner up to a fixed pin then climb past a few bolts on mostly jugs to anchors.
content.protection: 1 fixed pin and 3 bolts. Chains up top.
content.location: This route is located on the backside of Turret rock. Head down the gulley towards Rabbit Tracks and follow the backside of the fin to a large brushy alcove. About midway along the wall look for a large corner leading to a short overhang with prominent chains dangling. There are a few loose looking 12s to the left.

content.description: Obvious corner - look for chains to the right of a large corner.  Starts under a big downpull with a cupped indentation to the right.  Head right up the corner to slabby finish.  This is a sweet route.
content.protection: Mostly small to meduim SLCDs.  There are placements for some stoppers and at least one knob that can be slung on the top half.

content.description: fun chimney climb 25 ft left of catapiller corner. pretty easy climbing although most peeps would prolly say 5.6 but i thought 5.5 was good. good prodeep in the chimney. varries from chimney to squeeze to a lil  off width thrown in. gotta wrestle 3 trees on the way up.great beginer route.not sure on the order of routes but its right in this bunch can summit the turret from here with a lil 5.easy. But it down climbs a lil goofy. Could also set up top ropes for most of the routes on either side
content.protection: i used almost all cams to camalot #4. might have thrown in a hex.long runners. pro was deep in the chimney. ran it out to the anchors up top
content.location: chimney 25 ft right of cattapiller corner

content.description: Starts on the face to the right of Caterpiller Corner.  Trust your feet moves on face with crimpers for your hands.  Follow the bolts and move into the corner for protection when it starts to lay down.  You can lead Caterpiller Corner to setup a top rope, then walk straight up the slab for even more fun.
content.protection: Visible bolts on face and small to meduim SLCDs and stoppers in corner on top half.

content.description: Fun gear protected laybacking for the first 30' to exciting face climbing. Frictiony feel for the feet...
content.location: At the apex of the south and east side of Bare Ass.

content.description: This is a really fun route with the crux coming at the roof near the top.  Watch out for the hollow flake in the middle of the route.  Besides this, the rock is great quality and the route is well protected.  Although graded harder, I felt the crux here was easier than the crux on Mousetrap.
content.protection: Bolts with chains at the top.
content.location: This route is just left of the large offwidth, which is itself left of Caterpillar Corner.

content.description: Like most of the stuff around Windy Point, Turret Rocks is a group of towers with climbing on all aspects (read: shade chasing).  Moderate trad climbing, and 5.10 to 5.12 sport climbing prevails.  For moderate trad, I suggest Jambrosia 5.8** on the tower by the same name, and Rabbit Tracks 5.6***.  The latter is especially great for the new leader.  I have only done one sport climb there, but they all look great.
